list_definition.definition: a part of some plants, insects etc, eg nettles and wasps, that can prick and inject an irritating or poisonous fluid into the wound.
an act of piercing with this part

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Some spiders give a poisonous sting.

list_definition.definition: the wound, swelling, or pain caused by this

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: You can soothe a wasp sting by putting vinegar on it.

list_definition.definition: to wound or hurt by means of a sting

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The child was badly stung by nettles/mosquitoes

list_definition.definition: (of a wound, or a part of the body) to smart or be painful

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The salt water made his eyes sting.

list_ex_of_english: But, and here comes the sting, getting rid of the rationality axiom as a foundational postulate does not get rid of all problems.
The moral sting that commonly accrues to "selfish" is thus removed.
He did the old bits with suitable stinging irony but this only made them funnier and got him more depressed.
In prospect theory, loss delivers this exaggerated sting because losses are measured against the actor's reference point, not the actor's net asset position.
When the larva has been stung the female may withdraw her ovipositor, or wait with it in the cocoon.
Musical stories take the sting out of the repetition so often used in modern teaching to reinforce certain concepts.
According to his semantic sting argument, semantic theories of law are inconsistent with the existence of pivotal disagreement about the grounds of law.
Nor is criterialism, properly or sympathetically understood, vulnerable to the semantic sting.
